data.que: What is meant by coordination in multicellular organisms?
data.ans: Integration of functions and responses between organs and systems.

data.que: Name the two main regulatory systems in animals.
data.ans: Nervous system and endocrine (hormonal) system.

data.que: What is a neuron?
data.ans: A nerve cell that transmits electrical impulses.

data.que: Define synapse.
data.ans: Junction between two neurons where impulses pass chemically.

data.que: What is a reflex action?
data.ans: A rapid, involuntary response to a stimulus without conscious control.

data.que: Give an example of a reflex action.
data.ans: Removal of hand from a hot object (withdrawal reflex).

data.que: What are receptors?
data.ans: Specialised cells or organs that detect stimuli from the environment.

data.que: What is an effector?
data.ans: A muscle or gland that produces a response to a stimulus.

data.que: Name the parts of a neuron.
data.ans: Cell body, dendrites, and axon.

data.que: What is the role of myelin sheath?
data.ans: Insulates axon and speeds up impulse conduction.

data.que: Differentiate between sensory and motor neurons.
data.ans: Sensory neurons carry impulses to the CNS; motor neurons carry impulses away to effectors.

data.que: What is the central nervous system (CNS)?
data.ans: Brain and spinal cord that process information.

data.que: What is the peripheral nervous system (PNS)?
data.ans: All nerves outside the brain and spinal cord connecting CNS to organs.

data.que: What is the function of the spinal cord?
data.ans: Transmits impulses and coordinates simple reflexes.

data.que: Name the three layers of meninges briefly.
data.ans: Dura mater, arachnoid, and pia mater — protective coverings of the CNS.

data.que: What is a stimulus?
data.ans: Any change in the environment that elicits a response from an organism.

data.que: What is the endocrine system?
data.ans: A system of glands that secrete hormones into the blood.

data.que: Give two examples of endocrine glands.
data.ans: Pituitary gland and thyroid gland.

data.que: What are hormones?
data.ans: Chemical messengers released by endocrine glands carried by blood.

data.que: State one function of the pituitary gland.
data.ans: Controls other endocrine glands by releasing regulating hormones.

data.que: How does the endocrine response differ from nervous response?
data.ans: Endocrine is slower but longer-lasting; nervous is rapid but short-lived.

data.que: What is feedback regulation?
data.ans: Mechanism where hormone levels are regulated by feedback to maintain balance.

data.que: What causes watery eyes when onion is cut?
data.ans: Stimulation of tear glands by irritant vapours activating reflex pathways.

data.que: Define voluntary action.
data.ans: A deliberate action under conscious control, e.g., walking.

data.que: What is the role of cerebrum?
data.ans: Higher brain functions — thinking, memory, and voluntary actions.

data.que: What is the role of cerebellum?
data.ans: Coordinates posture and balance and fine muscle movements.

data.que: Why are reflex arcs important?
data.ans: They protect the body by producing rapid automatic responses to danger.

data.que: Mention one example of hormonal coordination in plants.
data.ans: Auxin controls phototropism causing plant stems to bend toward light.
